Good morning, I'm David Greene with a pretty enticing offer - beer internship.
You know how sometimes in life you make a friend, and at first it's really intense?
You talk with your heads close together.
You try to tell her everything about yourself over tea and white wine.
And you think that all that sharing will make you close forever, but it doesn't really work that way.
Friendships change a lot.
And I think books can be like that, too.
They can shift and then you have all these complicated feelings when you have to adjust your expectations.
I feel this way about Susanna Sonnenberg's memoir, ""She Matters: A Life in Friendships."" Her descriptions totally drew me in, like this friend from summer camp.
She stood next to me and we held in our stomachs when Greg La Rosa ambled by and said, hi.
She explained marshmallow spread as we sat down with trays of Fluffernutter sandwiches.
Sonnenberg tells us, she made me a peach-pit ring and I made her a peach-pit ring.
On my last day we said, how can I live without you?
It's like Judy Bloom perfection.
When Sonnenberg gets older, she realizes some of her friends can live without her.
There are some really bad breakups in this book.
One is her college roommate from 25 years ago sends her a letter.
What she remembered of our acquaintance was that she hated me, Sonnenberg writes.
Another time she has a relaxed lunch with a friend and then gets this email that's so blunt it's like a wartime telegram.
I can't be friends with you anymore, it says.
I felt sad for her.
She has this really amazing lack of vanity that I loved, even if I was a little taken aback by her intensity.
She actually made me wonder about my own friendships.
If I wrote them all down like this, would they look this fraught?
At first I thought the memoir was basically a beautifully written, emotional and nostalgic look at the way women become friends.
In the end, it's also really a book about boundary issues.
But in between is where all the meat is.
It's the part that makes you question what a friend really is.
You're not related to them and you're not married to them.
So what exactly do you owe each other?
What are the rules?
Susanna Sonnenberg doesn't answer that.
But she has written something that manages to interest, to exhaust, to impress and, yes, to matter.

Now to New Orleans, where a federal judge has created a security zone around BP's collapsed oil rig.
It's the legal equivalent of taking yellow police tape, and draping it around the watery crime scene.
In this case, the potential crime involves the catastrophic oil spill that's threatened the Gulf.
And even though the investigation is taking place underneath the water's surface, NPR's Carrie Johnson reports there's a lot going on at the Justice Department.
The Justice Department wants everyone to know it hasn't forgotten about the oil spill this year.
Gary Grindler is the department's second-in-command, and he described the investigation this way.
This investigation is a very high priority for the Department of Justice.
So senior officials, up to the top, are very involved.
Over the past several months, top-ranking Justice officials, including Grindler, visited the Gulf to look at critical pieces of evidence, like the four-story-high blowout preventer.
A tremendous number of resources are being devoted to this.
There are at least 40 attorneys that are involved in both the civil division and the criminal side of the house.
We have U.S.
attorneys' offices along the Gulf that have been affected, that are actively involved.
David Uhlmann used to be a prosecutor.
These days, he teaches at the University of Michigan, but he's closely following the oil spill investigation.
Proving that there was negligence on the criminal side, proving that there was an oil spill on the civil side, these are relatively easy matters for them to prove, based on what we already know.
Uhlmann says criminal charges against BP and Transocean, which operated the rig, could be a foregone conclusion.
The only real issue, he says, is how much the companies will pay to settle allegations they released oil into the Gulf.
the corporate culture of BP, and how it may have foreshadowed the rig disaster.
And then the really big question mark is what will happen with individuals.
If the Justice Department decides that there are individuals who should be charged, it's very likely that they would contest the charges, because they could go to jail.
In the last 10 years, what we've seen is a tendency just to go with the corporate plea.
That's Jane Barrett.
She's a former prosecutor.
In particular, the individuals that get charged are those who are affiliated with - you know, not with your Fortune 200 companies, but smaller companies.

Barrett says it can be difficult to prove any one employee knows enough about safety problems to become the target of criminal charges - so difficult that the federal Justice Department never charged the captain of the Exxon Valdez with wrongdoing after that disaster.
But Grindler, the deputy attorney general, says authorities are considering every legal tool at their disposal.
There are a number of statutes that are clearly at play: the Clean Water Act, the Oil Pollution Act, the Migratory Bird Act and the Endangered Species Act.
Carrie Johnson, NPR News, Washington.

After weeks of uncertainty, Robert Mugabe was declared the winner of a runoff election and sworn in for a sixth term as Zimbabwe's president.
Mugabe was the only candidate in the race after opposition leader Morgan Tsvangirai withdrew amid claims of state-sponsored violence and intimidation.
Leaders around the world have condemned the vote as a sham.
On the phone is Zimbabwe's ambassador to the United States, Machivenyika Mapuranga.
Ambassador, thanks for joining us.
You're welcome.
So when you have spoken with people in Zimbabwe who are telling you, describing to you the situation on the ground, what kind of a description are you getting of what things are like in Harare?
Everything is back to normal.
The situation is quiet.
Obviously, those members of the ruling party who saw the triumph of their president in the runoff election may be celebrating in their houses.
And those of the opposition may be ruing in their houses.
But I've been in touch with Harare since the runoff election, and everything is back to normal.

Zimbabwe's young men and young women who have gotten, in many cases, such a good education in the Zimbabwean system, then grow up and often find that there's no place for them to put their skills to work.
There are people of Zimbabwean descent and citizenship in the U.K., the U.S., Australia, South Africa, all around the world.
What are you going to do to get them back?
Well, at the moment, our economy has been affected by the dysfunctions that the West imposed after we decided to redistribute land equitably between the races.
And so we are going through a rough patch.
And we think that within the next few years the economy is going to be revived.
When that occurs, the indigenous people will be in charge.
We will not be a neo-colony of the British, as we have been hitherto.
And so, by the way, Zimbabwe's not the only country that has people in the Diaspora.
There are more Ghanaians or Nigerians, you know, and so forth in the Diaspora than Zimbabweans.
It's just that for Zimbabwe it is a recent phenomenon as a result of the rough economic patch we're going through.
But do you think - I mean, you know, you bring up the issue of the West.
Right now, President Bush is calling for an international arms embargo and drafting new economic sanctions.
How are you going to operate in the face of widespread tightening of sanctions by the West?
Mark my word.
Please mark my word.
President Bush is wasting his time because the Chinese know what it is all about.
It's about Western control of Africa's resources.
They know - the Russians also know what the game that the British and the Americans are playing in Africa and particularly in Zimbabwe.
And they will not let the UN Security Council impose an arms embargo on Zimbabwe just because Zimbabwe refuses to be controlled by the British and the Americans.
Most people don't have everyday concerns that stretch to geopolitics that affect many, many nations.
They're concerned with things that are right at home.

Do you think that Zimbabwe, in part because of the nature of the political discourse right now, will fall back into a situation where it has certain patron states, perhaps China and Russia, and certain states that it is, you know, there's antipathy, like the U.K.
and the U.S.?
Well, the Cold War is over.
We do not have a socialist camp.
The capitalist camp is still there.
But as far as Zimbabwe is concerned, it's not about this camp or that camp.
Zimbabwe is just about to strengthen its control of its natural resource.
We have passed legislation recently to extend what happened on the land reform front, to extend it to other fronts like the minerals and industry and so forth.
So it's about the empowerment of the people of Zimbabwe.
And this struggle, in my view, is very clear to, you know, countries in the Third World that once were the victims of colonialism and imperialism.
That's why none of them is condemning us or agreeing that we should be isolated.
We have friends in, you know, in Asia, Africa, Latin America.
The only ones that want to seek to control our natural resources are our former colonial master, Britain, and its allies.
Let's look ahead.
If you look down the road, say, 20 years, what do you want to see Zimbabwe look like, and what do you expect?
And of course, none of us is promised any specific number of days on this earth, but President Mugabe may well be gone by then.
He may well be gone well before then.
Right.
What the government of Zimbabwe would like to see is a peaceful and developed and prosperous country whose population has control over their natural resources.
And we wish this not just for Zimbabwe, but for Africa because Africa will never, never, ever develop until they have control of their natural resources.
And Africa will not develop from handouts.
One last question before I let you go.
There are a lot of people in rural areas, in Mashonaland, in - even in urban areas, who just don't have enough food to eat.
What is the government going to do about that in the short term?
You know, as we speak now, we are involved in the largest farm mechanization program Africa has ever seen.
And in the course of that we have distributed tens of thousands of plows, thousands of tractors, and we are actually building a factory for tractors.
We are also building a plant for fertilizers.
So we have focused on agriculture.
